results.title: Landscape as Character
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

constellations_primary.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_primary.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
description_for_label:

We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.

results.title: VFX in American Gods
results.credit_line:
Title sequence creative director: Patrick Clair
Courtesy Fremantle
results.brief_description: A look at the acclaimed title sequence from American Gods, by VFX studio Antibody.

constellations_primary.name: The world's end
constellations_primary.description: For people of colour oppressed by systemic racism, genre stories about the end of the world and cosmological monsters can be used to re-examine race and the injustices faced in real life.

results.description: Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman’s source material to life.
description_for_label:
Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman’s source material to life.

No photography

results.title: Portable TVs (Retro Vision)
results.brief_description: Australians loved portable TVs. How else could you watch cricket at the beach or take your favourite show camping? Despite how portable these units were, due to using batteries, their small stature saw them positioned in the home just as much as the great outdoors, and they gradually became more of a fashion statement during the late 1970s and 80s. The most fashionable of the ones displayed here is easily the JVC Videosphere, which came in red, black, white and orange, and was designed to look like a space helmet, in homage to 2001: A Space Odyssey and the popularity of the Space Race in 1970 when it was released. It’s since appeared as props in Hollywood films and in video artist Nam June Paik’s installation, TV Buddha (1974).

results.title: Videosphere 'Space Helmet' CRT Television Set
results.brief_description:
Videosphere was a JVC CRT television that was shaped in the form of a space helmet. It was first introduced in 1970 and was sold up until the early-1980s. It was popular for its modern design; the alarm clock base was an option however most units have a plain base.

Videospheres were produced in large quantities in white, red, black and orange in the seventies with a grey colored model also released in the 1980s. The design of the videosphere is said to have been inspired by the film 2001: A Space Odyssey,[1] though the videosphere’s shape in itself remains as one of the most iconic examples of the early 1970s design ethos.

The sci-fi look of the TV saw a red model appear as a background prop in the 1999 film The Matrix, though they have appeared in sci-fi films since the early 70s. Soylent Green had a red model on screen as a prop.The 1972 film Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, a black videosphere was shown with a color capable tube and a slot that allowed a cassette tape capable of playing video. Humorously, the color image on the videosphere goes from being rectangular in one scene to round in another scene.

JVC Videosphere / Made in Japan / (Yokohama) / Serial # 10600147
240 V / 50Hz / 12V / 11W (Australian AC power plug). Has plastic casing, control dials positioned at the back of object with an aerial and chain to hang unit.

results.title: Pop-Up Television Radio Model TR-475U
results.material_description: plastic body with silver metal handle, trim and antenna.
results.brief_description:
National Transistor TV. Model TR-475U. Pop-up screen and pull out handle for portablity.
No power cords, batteries only.

Brand: National

Serial no. F 3 (??) 1113
TQF8125

National Transistor TV
Model TR-475U DC12V 11W
Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd
Made in Japan
TBM 81685

Caution: To prevernt electric shock, do not remove cover. No user-serviceable parts inside, and pilot lamp soldered in place. Refer servicing to qualified service personnel.

Note: Before opening the pop-up portion of this TV. Please release two red screws fixed on the bottom side of the set. These screws are fixed for delivery safety only. The battery enclosed in this TV receiver is disconnected to assure longer life.

Before use, it must be properly connected. Please see instruction manual. For longer battery life: charge more than 10 hours before initial use. After each use once a month.

There are no power cords accompanying the TV.
results.description:
The National Transistor TV Radio Model TR-475U is a battery-operated, portable model features an inbuilt radio and a ‘pop-up’ television screen.
National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: National Ranger 505 Transistor TV
results.creator_credit: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.description:
National Ranger 505 Transistor TV is a portable TV with handle, small screen and folding antennae. The television was completely portable - it could be powered with either mains power or batteries, allowing the user to kick back and take the TV to the beach, campground or backyard.

National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: Early home consoles
results.brief_description: While the first home console, the Magnavox Odyssey, came out in 1972, it wasn’t the only launched in the decade. Around 1978, the two-player Hanimex TVG-8610C console was released for home use. Featuring detachable joysticks and 10 internally programmed games, it allowed players to customise difficulty levels, automation and keep score. Console like this needed to be run through the home TV to use as a monitor and also required a little domestic diplomacy with family members for a bigger share of screen time.

results.title: TVG-8610C Console
results.brief_description: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020
results.description: The Hanimex TVG-8610C is an early television games console circa 1978. This two-player console has detachable joysticks with 10 internally programmed games (similar to Pong) and allows the player to customise difficulty levels, automation, and keep score.
description_for_label: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020

results.title: Commodore 64 Console and Cassettes
results.brief_description: Consoles and personal computers are common in homes today, but back in 1982 they were pretty rare. Enter the Commodore 64, a wildly popular 8-bit home computer console that was a major contributor to the home computer revolution. With over 17 million units sold worldwide, it was the highest selling single computer at the time and was often used to run educational resources and games. In Australia alone, over 700 games were produced for the Commodore 64. Software was originally released on audio cassette before 5 ¼ inch floppy discs (and later 3½ inch floppy discs) became more common during the 1980s, which we’ve worked to locate, acquire and preserve.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.
